channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Perl for High Performance; Senior Developer, London

item.description: Picture this. Itâ€™s a weekday morning. You get on the underground, head into London, near Kings Cross, with all the miserable commuters. The only difference between you and them? Youâ€™re not miserable!

item.description: I never thought about writing about Perl6 but here you go I share my first encounter with Perl6.

item.title: Lexical readonly state variables with PerlX::Let
item.description: Robert recently released PerlX::Let introducing new keword "let", read further to find out more.

item.title: Mojolicious and DBIx::Class
item.description: A complete guide how to use DBIx::Class with Mojo app by Doug Bell.

item.title: 9 Books Every Professional Should Read in 2019
item.description: Gene shares the secrets of reading. There's a good reason the most successful people in the world share a love of books. By reading experts' insights, anyone can emulate the strategies of the best and brightest.

item.title: Falsehoods Programmers Believe About Phone Numbers
item.description: Arun talks about the different shapes and forms of Phone Numbers.

item.title: What makes a great entrepreneur?
item.description: Whether youâ€™re starting your first business or youâ€™ve been working in your niche for decades (but have a great idea), the truth is that there is always something to learn in the business world.

item.title: The #! magic
item.description: Sven shares the magic of #!. Referesh your memory with regard of the history of shebang.

item.title: The case of the supersized shebang
item.description: Jonathan explains the change in the handling of shebang lins in 5.0 kernel. Interesting take, highly recommended.

item.title: Adding a Gravatar to PAUSE Account
item.description: Mike shares the secret how to add profile image to their PAUSE account.

item.title: AWS Perl Lambdas - openssl issue
item.description: Rob shares issues gettng HTTPS to work with LWP in a Lambda.

item.title: Software engineer happiness matters
item.description: In the never-ending quest for greater developer productivity, security and compliance usually seem like monkey wrenches in the machinery. These aspects of development are essential, but they can slow down the flow of work and frustrate developers.

item.title: Variable-Length Lookbehinds: actually possible in Perl/PCRE!
item.description: John talks about the topic that never got the due. I always find myself lost with this feature of regex.

item.title: About the Various PANs
item.description: Olaf took the time to explain various PANs that somehow got lost in the air. I sometimes get confused with so many PANs. Now I have a reference point to onfirm.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge
item.description: Here I talk about newly introduced challenge for Perl lovers. Please join the group.

item.title: Swiss Perl Workshop 2019 - One Week Left To Choose The Dates
item.description: That's right, there is one week left on our poll to choose the dates for this year's Swiss Perl Workshop. If you're a regular to the workshop, or you are thinking about attending for the first time, then make your choice known.

item.title: Get the most affordable premium labels for your business at StickerYou.com
item.description: Are you tired of spending your hard-earned dollars on labels that look cheap? Imagine if you could get far superior labels at a much lower cost. Well at StickerYou.com, you can! Order high-quality labels for your business, your family, your staff. StickerYou.comâ€™s online editor allows you to customize them in an endless number of shapes and sizes in minutes. Best of all there are no minimum order quantities! Better yet, use code PERL10 at checkout for 10% off.

item.title: #396 - Perl Weekly Challenge
item.description:
Hi there

Last week, Gabor Szabo, the Chief Editor of PerlWeekly newsletter started the campaign to involve readers and asked what they want to read in the future newsletter. Taking a clue from it, I came up with the idea of "Perl Weekly Challenge". I am certain this is not the first time anyone tried it. Still I want to revive it primarily to engage the Perl enthusiasts. It can be Perl5 or Perl6. My first target is to setup a team who are interested in the weekly challenge. Then we will throw some random challenge to public and see how many different results we get back. We can then pick one as winner, put it on "Hall of Fame". We could encourage the winner to share the answer to the challenge as a small blog.

I wrote a blog about it last week. I already had an email the very same day by a perl lover, interested in the challenge. I am looking for more people to join the challenge before we go live.

Last but not the least, please do share what you would want to read.
